item.title: Nintendo Partner Direct live report - what third-party surprises has Switch 2 got?
item.content:encoded:
Show starts 2pm UK time.

Live

There's a Nintendo Direct broadcast happening today, focusing on non-Nintendo Switch and Switch 2 games, and we'll be covering everything divulged right here. You know the drill: watch along, chat along, possibly make a pithy remark. Or be refreshingly positive - it's up to you!

What we know: the Nintendo Partner Direct will begin at 2pm UK time and will be short and sweet with a running-time of 30 minutes. No need to stay up half the night for this one - mentioning no names, ahem, Sony.

What we don't know: what will be in the broadcast. There aren't any official sighters to go by, which means we have plenty to speculate about. Are we about to get a release date for Elden Ring on Switch 2, for example? And speaking of FromSoftware: what's going on with Switch 2-exclusive The Duskbloods? You can't just dangle that in front of us one year and then not say anything about it, can you?

Beyond that, maybe we'll get a release date for Indiana Jones and the Great Circle on Switch 2, and potentially something about the second Final Fantasy 7 game Rebirth coming to Switch 2 - there are rumours.

Regardless, it's theoretically a good moment for third-party games on Switch 2, while Nintendo's new console has comparable power, so let's see how the Switch 2 capitalises on it.



https://www.eurogamer.net/nintendo-switch-partner-direct-february-2026-live-report
item.dc:creator: invalid@example.com (ResetEra_Newsbot

item.title: Hollow Knight has been rated for Nintendo Switch 2 - and just before a Nintendo Direct
item.content:encoded:
Hollow Knight has received a PEGI rating for the Switch 2, hinting towards a port to the latest Nintendo console.

As can be seen on the PEGI website, the beloved metroidvania can be seen rated across all its console versions. However, if you peer down at the base version of Hollow Knight (not the Voidheart Edition) you can see a Switch 2 version rated today, the 5th February 2026.

This comes at a peculiar time, as we have a Nintendo Partner Direct to look forward to later today at 2PM GMT / 3PM CEST / 6AM PST / 9AM EST. Perhaps this is a early indicator of a reveal to come.

Hollow Knight hasn't become a household name without cause. The game has an extremely compelling guiding hand that urges players to explore a collection of endearing, often gorgeous, sometimes horrifying, locations that are both lovingly-crafted and packed with weaving narratives.

If you've not actually played the original Hollow Knight yet, perhaps you jumped first into Silksong or just haven't found the time, it's an absolute must-play. You can read Eurogamer's review of Hollow Knight here, in which Vikki Blake describes the game as: "A stern yet scintillating 2D adventure that makes a point of not holding your hand."

Hollow Knight

PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X/S, PC, Mac, Nintendo Switch

Related topics


https://www.eurogamer.net/hollow-knight-rated-nintendo-switch-2-before-a-nintendo-direct

item.title: Nintendo ambassador Charles Martinet hadn't even heard of the Japanese company when he auditioned for Mario
item.content:encoded:
Original Mario voice actor Charles Martinet has shared more on how he came up with the voice for Nintendo's moustachioed plumber.

Back in 2023, Nintendo announced that Martinet, the exuberant voice of Mario, would no longer be the English voice actor behind Nintendo's most recognisable mascot, after almost 30 years in the job. Starting with Super Mario Bros. Wonder, the role was instead taken on by Kevin Afghani, while Martinet became a Mario Ambassador.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

But, how did Martinet actually come up with the 'whoops' and 'wahoooooos' of Mario? Well, first off, it turns out that Martinet actually crashed Nintendo's audition for Mario without knowing anything about the character. In fact, he didn't even know anything about Nintendo. But even so, he had "so much fun at the audition" many decades ago, and soon his iconic legacy began.

"I was simply told to start talking, and when you run out of things to say, that's your audition," Martinet told GamingBible. "I didn't want to do an Italian plumber sounding gruff, mean and nasty or scary to children, like a Mafia member. I didn't know whether the audience would have children in it, but I have a principle of comedy of always being kind. I thought to myself that I'll do something much more silly and fun. I didn't know anything about video games, so I just made things up about food and started talking."

Martinet added that "being able to bring that joy into children's and adults' lives" has been a "tremendous honour" for him.

"When they tell me stories of growing up with Mario, and playing the games with their parents, grandparents, and now their children, it gives me such a feeling of joy that cannot be described. I'm just grateful for those moments every day."

Since his turn as the voice of Mario in the games, Martinet did have a rather charming cameo in the Super Mario Bros. Movie. Here, he voiced Mario and Luigi's father. Mario and Luigi's father appears in multiple scenes during the film's opening section in Brooklyn, and again at the end, when Bowser's castle comes crashing back through to the "human" world.

At one point, we hear Mario and Luigi's father congratulating his sons by saying: "That's my boys!" Awww! I wonder if he will return for The Super Mario Galaxy Movie, as well…?

Related topics
